Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: This is an excellent question but difficult / controversial to answer. There are two reasons to do pelvic lymph node dissection (PLND). 1) to help with staging (i.e. to detect metastasis) in which case the patient may decide whether or not he would like the surgeon to continue. 2) it is potentially therapeutic (i.e. if there is microscopic metastasis to a few nodes and they are all removed this may result in a cure, however the data on this is somewhat conflicted. Here are some papers showing potential benefit: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2997840/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1950746/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=15540734 The reason not to do it is there is the potential for complications - primarily lympocele. Lympocele is usually minor and easily managed but rarely can cause significant chronic problems (e.g. lymphedema in the legs) As with many aspects of surgery, I imagine the incidence of sequelae depend in great part on the skill of the surgeon and the post-op clinical protocol employed. The literature shows a wide variation in reported incidence of lymphoceles. A study from University of Chicago (Orvieto et. al.) using post-op CT detected lymphoceles in 39 of 76 patients (51%) however only 6 of 76 (7.9%) were clinically symptomatic. On the other hand, a paper from Hopkins (Allaf et. al.) reported lymphocele in only 3 out of 4000 patients (<0.1%) Dr. Walsh addresses this issue in his book and explains that due to the potential benefit and low rate of complications (which are typically easily manageable when they due occur) it was made institutional policy at Johns Hopkins to perform lymph node dissection for all patients: "one out of one hundred times, lymph nodes turn out to be positive in a patient in whom you would least expect it. Because we have found that these are also the exact patients who would benefit most from having these lymph nodes removed, we continue to do lymph node dissections in all patients. We are emboldened to do this because of the extremely low risk of complications associated with this, the ease with which a complete lymph node dissection can be performed in a short time, and the fact that more good can come from it than not." but Walsh also states that, given the declining rate of node positivity it is "understandable" for surgeons to omit dissection. Another Doctor with whom I consulted, Arieh Shalhav (Chief of Urology at University of Chicago -- where the one paper above came from reporting 7.9% incidence of clinically symptomatic lympocele) was adamant that I should have lymph node dissection because he said he had been “burned too many times” by apparently low risk patients whose finally pathology turns out significantly worse and told me that while "annoying" lympocele is easily managed. Dr. Burnett from Hopkins who did my surgery also stressed the potential benefit benefit and stated that open RRP facilitates a better job of PLND. My personal opinion is for a young healthy guy who is going to go through surgery the small incremental risk is negligible and well worth it for maximizing the possibility of cure.

Did not have typical diffusion-weighted features of high-grade PCa. No evidence of ECE, NVB, SV or LN involvement. May '13: Open RRP by Dr. Burnett @ Hopkins. Both nerves spared. Final Pathology: GS 3+3, organ confined (tumor extent moderate), SV and 11 nodes all negative (pT2a). Negative margins! Posts.Content: This is very puzzling / concerning in a couple respects... 1) I believe studies show better likelihood of cure when salvage is done at 0.2 than if you wait. 2) Moreover, C-11 PET choline scan is used to detect distant recurrence (bone or possibly lymph node mets) so if you wait to see something on that scan it is likely too late to cure with salvage radiation. I would ask Dr. Kwon to explain / answer each of these two concerns. If you want another opinion from probably the top expert in the world on handling potential recurrence contact Dr. d'Amico at Dana Farber. Perhaps he will even give you a 2nd opinion remotely.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BigbirdPhila Many posters here recommend researching positive (or negative) surgical margin rates for evaluating a surgeon's skill. I would be particularly interested in researching their results with T1c cases, which is my current stage. I've tried many Google searches and several searches here in the PC Forum but am coming up with blanks. Can someone point me to where I can start researching published numbers for RALP surgeons? Are these kinds of numbers available only for "big time" surgeons who have tabulated their data and published a study? With a few exceptions you won't be able to find out a surgeon's margin rates without asking him/her. The exceptions are surgeons who have published their results in medical journals. When I was looking for a surgeon in 2013, I read as many of those journal papers as I could locate and I compiled my findings in a spreadsheet, which I have posted here as a Google Doc (please note that I have not updated this since 2013): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets...kf2x9v15dm5LjY Although these are all high volume surgeons at top institutions the variability among their results is striking. Since you hope to find a local surgeon, you should just ask them for their results during a consultation appointment. Specifically I recommend you ask the following questions: "What is your positive surgical margin rate for pathalogic stage T2 (stage pT2) patients?" "What is your positive surgical margin rate for pathalogic stage T3 (stage pT3) patients?" Although you can also ask about their PSM rates by patients' clinical stage (cT1c in your case), this is actually NOT the best way to compare one surgeon to another because there can be great variability among clinical T1c patients based on other risk factors like Gleason score and PSA. For example, a clinical T1c patient who is G9 with a PSA of 20 is much more likely to turn out to have pathalogic stage pT3 or pT4 (where positive margins are hard to avoid) than you being clinical T1c G6 with PSA of only 4.5. Pathologic stage on the other hand provides a more apples-to-apples comparison. In particular, comparing only PSM rates for actual pT2 patients (who have organ confined disease / no extra-capsular extension, which is the best case scenario) and essentially any positive surgical margins that occur with such patents are iatrogenic (i.e. the surgeon nicking into the prostate capsule and leaving part of it -- including tumor -- inside the patient). Unfortunately because RP is so tricky this happens to the even the best surgeons sometimes (less than 2% of pT2 patients) but with most other surgeons it may occur with around 10% or more on the same type of pT2 patients that have organ confined disease. Any surgeon you interview should be able to readily and precisely answer these questions (and if they can't or won't that would be a big red flag). If you can't find a local doctor with results approaching the best (i.e. lowest) numbers in my spreadsheet -- particularly if their PSM rate for stage pT2 is much more than 2% (which is quite possible), then don't be afraid to travel to a surgeon who has published top results. All that said, since your stats are pretty low risk and you are 66 years old I would encourage you to strongly consider your other options like brachytherapy (but also only with a top practitioner), SBRT, or active surveillance. Although a top surgeon can maximize the likelihood of a good outcome, there is a real possibility of some significant / lingering side effects from the surgery.

Posts.Title: Researching A Surgeon's Surgical Margin Rates

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LILDOG Can nerve sparing cause psa to become detectable ( with ultra sensitve assay ) or rise after prostate surgery ? With any RP surgery there can be bits of prostate left behind, but yes this is probably more likely with nerve sparing because the surgeon is cutting much closer to the prostate to free the delicate web of nerves from its capsule and it is relatively common to "nick" the capsule. Any prostate left behind could be benign and/or malignant depending on where the tumor is located relative to any nicks through the capsule. When you have a positive surgical margin there is a much stronger suspicion that malignant cells were left behind. However, as explained in Dr. Walsh's book, this is not always the case because you can have false positive margins. As also explained in Walsh's book, even if some malignant cells were left behind at the margin, they may not actually survive the trauma of surgery. In particular, many believe that if the GS at the PSM is 3+3 those cells are less likely to survive than higher GS cells. As you know, the purpose of your periodic PSA test to look for indication of relatively high and increasing levels of PSA returning that would be suspicious for tumor re-growing. Bits of benign tissue can result in low but persistent / slowly increasing PSA levels. Donin et. al. describe this as "insignificant biochemical recurrence" (iBCR): "A PSA >0.2 ng/mL may develop because of local, lymphatic, or systemic recurrent prostate cancer or may be because of the presence of residual benign prostate tissue. Differentiating between these etiologies in the early stages of recurrence is not possible using presently available diagnostic technology. We have previously reported that microscopic benign prostate tissue is often identified at the apical and bladder neck soft tissue margins during RP and speculated that these benign glands may contribute to measureable PSA associated with prolonged PSA doubling time (PSADT). We have previously reported that a postprostatectomy PSA >0.2 ng/mL in association with a PSADT >36 months is attributable to residual benign microscopic prostatic elements. Men fulfilling these criteria in the present study were classified as exhibiting iBCR likely because of benign prostatic tissue and therefore none of these men were offered salvage radiation therapy (SRT)." see: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23706588 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19406457

Posts.Title: Nerve sparing and psa after rp !!!!!!

Posts.Content: Welcome K9, First, have you also had a DRE or just the PSAs? If you have not had a DRE you absolutely should have one. However even if the DRE and is normal, that is still no guarantee however, as most PC is diagnosed before it is palpable on DRE. Those PSA numbers are definitely high for your age (median PSA for 40-50 yr old men is only 0.7). This puts you well above the 90% percentile PSA level (1.5) and at much higher risk of death from aggressive PC by the age of 75. See http://www.mskcc.org/videos/psa-test...ssive-prostate. Also, assuming the readings were actually 12 months apart, your most recent PSA velocity of 2.0 - 1.6 = 0.4 ng/yr is above the 0.2 to 0.35 ng/yr thresholds that have previously been considered a red flag, however the value of PSA velocity for screening purposes is controversial with experts and studies conflicting and views changing over time. See E.g. (in order from most recent to oldest): http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/777868 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23706588 http://www.cancer.gov/clinicaltrials...a-velocity2011 http://www.mskcc.org/pressroom/press...edict-prostate http://www.cancernetwork.com/article...rostate-cancer http://www.mc.uky.edu/publichealth/d...0_Catalona.pdf http://www.drcatalona.com/quest/quest_fall06_1.asp http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer820.php A 2nd PSA to confirm the 2.0 value / .4 velocity and also check your % Free PSA may be a good idea. If you had sex, bicycled, or had the DRE prior to the blood draw, the 2.0 could have been artificially elevated. My first and only PSA was done this Jan after I turned 40 and came back 1.23 which is not alarmingly high and below the 2.5 threshold for my age, but I had an abnormal DRE that did turned out to be from PC. Although already relatively large (stage T2 palpable) tumor, fortunately it turned out to be non-aggressive Gleason 3+3. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Hi Rajah, You certainly would seem to still have options on the table besides chemo. In addition to Zytiga, Xtandi, Provenge, here are some ideas: Remarkable response to off-label use of Sprycel: www.healingwell.com/community/default.aspx?f=35&m=2727370 Ongoing trials of Cabozantinib (XL184): http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/re...&Search=Search Upcoming phase III trials of PROSTVAC-VF: http://www.healingwell.com/community...f=35&m=2783947 If you are not satisfied with how things go at Dana Farber, you may want to try an independent PCa oncologist like Snuffy Myers: http://www.prostateforum.com/about-dr-myers.html Best of luck to you...

Posts.Title: First Post M- CRPC What now?

Posts.Content: Hi Marty, While the risk of recurrence does continue to increase with time even out past 15 years, the slope gradually levels off so the incremental risk with each year is less and less. The apex is the most common location for positive margins with organ confined (pT2) disease due to the nature of the anatomy. If you are going to have positive margins, apical are probably the best as several studies suggest that they pose lower risk of recurrence than positive margins in other locations. Out of curiosity, how many nodes did you have taken out?

Posts.Title: Pathology Report and Sex

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gsteve Im leaning to da vinci for all the known reasons. Hi gsteve, What are those "known reasons" in your mind? The only clear advantage vs open is less blood loss and open has some advantages over robotic so it should come down to picking the surgeon who can offer you the best record of results and then leting him use whatever tools he uses. (I don't mean to sound like a broken record but I get the impression you missed what I said in the other thread and want to make sure you understand) I do agree with the others on the recovery process - with either open or robotic approach you'll probably feel great after 2 weeks, but you need to watch the lifting and other exertion or you risk a hernia. As far as the incision for open surgery, my doctor did everything through a only a single 3 inch incision that starts about 3 inches below my belly button and goes down from there. Because the muscle fibers run vertically they are not cut but just separated, which is by contrast to the circular trocars used for robotic (especially the one that needs to be enlarged to remove the intact specimen for pathology) that can cause more muscle trauma.

Posts.Title: da vinci recovery?

Posts.Content: I did extensive research on published outcomes -- not for robotic vs open per-se but for which specific surgeons had the best track record. I focused almost exclusively on oncological outcomes (surgical margin rates) vs continence or ED since both of those are less important than being cured and are also amenable to other therapies if necessary. The best surgical margin rates published were by open surgeons but a few robotic guys came pretty close. As far as continence my impression was little difference -- all good surgeons seemed to be 95%+ @ 1yr. ED is much more variable depending not only on the skill of the surgeon but on the patient's pre-op function, the extent of the disease, and how much risk the surgeon is willing to take to trading off nerve sparing vs. cancer control. I was told by the head of robotic surgery at Johns Hopkins that the only significant advantage to me from robotic vs open would be less blood loss. If you are interested, you can read my detailed account of my decision making process that I posted a couple weeks ago: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...t-op-(my-story) My #1 piece of advice to you would be to pick up Patrick Walsh's book (3rd ed. just updated). He invented nerve-sparing (anatomic) surgery, performed thousands of them, and ran the program at Hopkins for around 30 years. His book is excellent and addresses other treatments as well.

I thought it when to T3 (i.e. ECE). But you were just upgraded not up-staged. If your biopsy had been GS6, or if the final was GS9, the upgrade would be much more of a disappointment, but in the grand scheme of things I think this is an excellent report. Congratulations! The only thing that surprises me is that lymph node dissection was apparently not done even though you were already GS7 on biopsy. Was this discussed pre-op?

Posts.Title: continence?

Posts.Content: Good advice from Otago. I don't know the typical rates of "dying on the table" in prostateectomy but I am sure they are very low. Although it is a very tricky operation to do well (i.e. actually get all the cancer out and preserve nerves and continence), I don't believe it is unusually risky for a relatively healthy patient. The main risk would be from general anesthesia, which can be avoided by having open surgery with regional (spinal) anesthesia, which is what I did even though I was young and healthy. Robotic or other laproscopic surgery require general anesthesia. My main concern would 1) making sure surgery is the right option and 2) be finding the absolute best surgeon you can, even if that means traveling to a center of excellence like Johns Hopkins.

Posts.Title: Death rate while undergoing the robatic assisted prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dmm1987 You mentioned the doctor has no true way of knowing if its out of the prostate but the focus should be on if surgery is the best option. How do we determine if its the best if there is no way of knowing whether it is still localized to just the prostate? There is no way of knowing for sure before going in, but his chances can be predicted using nomograms such as the Partin tables Otago cited or the MSK nomogram: http://nomograms.mskcc.org/Prostate/PreTreatment.aspx An endorectal MRI could also give some more insight, but would not be absolutely conclusive. I assume he has at least had CT to look at pelvic lymph nodes and a bone scan? If his PSA was really 8 and Gleason is 9 then the cancer is less than 50% chance of being organ-confined and radiation without surgery (but still with hormone therapy) may be a better option to avoid the significant side effects of surgery. Unless there is some reason he couldn't have surgery a year ago it is strange that he did a year of hormone therapy first (neoadjuvant hormone therapy). Neoadjuvant hormone therapy is common before radiation but not before surgery.

Posts.Content: That makes more sense on why hormone therapy was done to buy time while he postponed treatment. Your father should really talk to a good radiation oncologist and a medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer. Surgery may not necessarily be the best option with his stats. For the record, the bill for my surgery at Johns Hopkins (probably the single best place in the world to have this particular surgery) with an extra couple days stay due to complications before insurance was only about $20k. Radiation treatments can run much more than that closer to $100k. I suggest you go out tomorrow and pick up a copy of Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer and read it cover to cover...

Posts.Content: That makes more sense on why hormone therapy was done to buy time while he postponed treatment. Your father should really talk to a good radiation oncologist and a medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer. Surgery may not necessarily be the best option with his stats. For the record, the bill for my surgery at Johns Hopkins (probably the single best place in the world to have this particular surgery) with an extra couple days stay due to complications before insurance was only about $20k. Radiation treatments can run much more than that closer to $100k. I suggest you go out tomorrow and pick up a copy of Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer and read it cover to cover...

Posts.Title: Death rate while undergoing the robatic assisted prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Anyway, he asked me how a negative margin could be a good indicator of the surgeon's expertise: Friend: "The Dr takes out the entire prostate, right?" Me: "yes" Unfortunately, no, often the surgeon often does not successfully take out the entire prostate. This is what happens when a patient with true organ-confined (stage pT2) disease ends up with a positive margin (see below). Originally Posted by ddayglo Friend: "Then if the margin is positive it means that the cancer spread and negative means it was contained, right" Me: "right" No. Again, many times posative margins actually occur despite the cancer being completely confined to the protate(no extra-prostatic extension) due to imperfect execution by the surgeon (see below). Originally Posted by ddayglo Friend: "If he takes out the entire prostate, if the margin was positive, then it doesn't have anything to do with the surgeon's expertise, but more to do with the progression of the cancer, wouldn't it?" I really didn't know how to answer him.... Advise appreciated. Thanks. Originally Posted by lLance ddayglo, I had the same question a while back. It was pointed out to me that if the surgeon missed getting all of it, there by leaving a positive margin that some how he was a bad surgeon. But my surgeon said that when doing the surgery they can't tell good tissue from bad. I get the impression that it is good guess work and luck. Short of actual biochemical recurrence, which unfortunately is very much a lagging indicator, positive surgical margin (PSM) rates are the best indicator of oncologic effectiveness (multiple studies show positive margins raise risk of eventual recurrence), so margins do matter! And there is substantial variation across surgeons - even among highly experienced surgeons operating on similar patients. While differences in pathological protocol (some labs having more false positives / false negatives based on how they process the specimen) may explain some variation, the best explanation for this is actual variation in surgical technique and skill. Given the same patient, some surgeons will be much more likely to achieve negative margins than others. I believe the best indicator of surgical skill is PSM rates for true pathologically organ-confined (stage pT2) disease. In this case the cancer was actually contained in the prostate so a PSM means the surgeon somehow managed to not remove the entire prostate! This happens to all surgeons sometimes but for the best surgeons the rate is less than 2% compared to 6%-10% for a good surgeon and much higher still for a average or worse surgeon. The most common causes for this are leaving bits of prostate tissue behind at the apex where it meets the pelvic floor muscles and the prostate has no capsule or inadvertently nicking into the capsule when dissecting away the nerve bundles or resecting the prostate out of the prostate bed. This is an iatrogenic (surgeon-caused) PSM. Both skill (including both steadiness of hand and judgement in discerning tissue planes) and technique (e.g. how aggressive the surgeon is in sparing nerves for a patient with given risk factors) influence this. For non-organ confined disease (stage pT3 / pT4) surgeon skill is again a factor. Despite extra-prostatic extension in many patients a great surgeon can still achieve negative margins 70-%-75% of the time by recognizing the EPE removing enough tissue to get all the cancer within the specimen removed and leave none behind in the prostate bed. I would be highly skeptical of any surgeon who denys this. If his PSM rates (if he will even give them to you) are significantly worse than world class, would he just try to claim that the world class surgeons who have consistently achieved <2% rates for pT2 patients have just gotten lucky for their thousands of cases? I'd tell him I'd take my chances with one of those "incredibly lucky" surgeons.

Posts.Content: Arthur Burnett performed my surgery the end of May and at that time they were still enrolling for this study. I opted not to participate because I would have had to return to Hopkins several times over the next year. To my knowledge Dr. Burnett did not actually develop the Viberect device (Reflexonic founder is urologist Kambiz Tajkarimi) but he has done prior studies suggesting that nerve stimulation can speed nerve recovery post-RP. Post-RP rehabilitation is not currently within the FDA approved indications for the the Viberect device ("home and clinic use to provoke penile erection in men with erectile dysfunction, and to provoke ejaculation in men with spinal cord injury") hence the current study being sponsored by Reflexonic and run by Burnett...

Posts.Title: Viberect

Posts.Content: Everyone's recovery is different, of course. I had complicated open surgery and required blood transfusions and extended hospital stay, but still I was able to resume most normal activities (driving, working, coaching soccer) in under 2 weeks as soon as the cath was out. I did need pads for a couple months, but still I was okay to go into the office within a couple weeks. I did have a 6-week lifting restriction (which is pretty typical I believe) so that could have been an issue if I was in a different line of work.

Posts.Title: What questions should I ask a radiology oncologist?

Posts.Content: The 2013 ASTRO / AUA joint guideline for radiation therapy after prostatectomy (http://www.auanet.org/common/pdf/edu...statectomy.pdf) recommends that clinicians define biochemical recurrence (BCR) as a detectable or rising PSA value after surgery that is ≥ 0.2 ng/ml with a second confirmatory level ≥ 0.2 ng/ml. However we are starting to see evidence that there may be a significant benefit from initiating salvage radiation sooner than 0.2, as explained here by the very knowable Allen Edel: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...on-save-lives/ Also see: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...ation-therapy/ http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21945099 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22795730 On the other hand, some doctors believe that even levels of ≥ 0.2 ng/ml are not worrisome IF the PSA doubling time is very long. Donin et. al. describe "insignificant biochemical recurrence" (iBCR) hypothetically due to bits of benign prostate tissue being left behind: "A PSA >0.2 ng/mL may develop because of local, lymphatic, or systemic recurrent prostate cancer or may be because of the presence of residual benign prostate tissue. Differentiating between these etiologies in the early stages of recurrence is not possible using presently available diagnostic technology. We have previously reported that microscopic benign prostate tissue is often identified at the apical and bladder neck soft tissue margins during RP and speculated that these benign glands may contribute to measureable PSA associated with prolonged PSA doubling time (PSADT). We have previously reported that a postprostatectomy PSA >0.2 ng/mL in association with a PSADT >36 months is attributable to residual benign microscopic prostatic elements. Men fulfilling these criteria in the present study were classified as exhibiting iBCR likely because of benign prostatic tissue and therefore none of these men were offered salvage radiation therapy (SRT)." see: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23706588 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19406457 What is your dad's PSA history? What were his post-op stats Gleason score, p-stage and margin status???

Posts.Title: Psa of 0.11 after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Congrats on expecting the new baby Omegaman! Your post-op pathology is a bit of a mixed bag. Of course you'd rather not see EPE, but it looks like the surgeon was able to get that all out. The fact that 42 nodes were taken out and were all clear should give you a lot of comfort. The positive margins at the apex are undesirable, but this the most common location for PSM and they often turn out to be inconsequential especially small focal margins like yours. In fact, according to Epstein, depending on the way the specimen is processed (shave margin vs perpendicular margin) the apex is sometimes prone to false positive margins. If I were you I would want to know the specific Gleason score at the location of the PSM. If it is GS3+3, that is less of a concern for several reasons and might make me lean towards a wait-and-see approach instead of pursuing adjuvant radiation since a recent paper (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23706588) seems to suggest that local recurrences arising from GS3+3 tumors have 100% response rate to salvage radiation if PSA ever does start to rise, which may never happen. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: Post-op pathology

Posts.Content: Good advice to hang around the hospital for a couple days to heal and recuperate and just in case any short-term post-op complications arise. But whenever you go home make sure you stop every hour or so and walk around. You should also be wearing compression stockings. For several weeks post op you are at significant risk for DVT (blood clot in legs) and pulmonary embolism (which is deadly)!

Posts.Title: Decision Made: Surgery, Dr. Tewari, 1/16

Posts.Content: If your catheter has only been out one week this sounds pretty normal. According to my surgeon, urinary control returns in 3 phases the first of which is being dry while lying down and being able to arise and walk to the bathroom without leaking. He says most patients achieve this first phase within three months, which indicates the lower sphincter is intact and functioning. I had open surgery at age 40. My catheter was in for 10 days and for the first week after it came out I leaked badly while standing or walking before having some significant improvement over the next two weeks. Then my progress plateaued for the next 3-4 weeks before another sudden leap of improvement. Don't over-do the Kegels or you will fatigue the muscles and leak badly! Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Although PC usually grows slowly, I agree that 4 months seems like a long time to wait to repeat for your peace of mind if nothing else. In the mean time, you should be trying a course of antibiotics probably for a month to rule out the most likely non-PC cause (prostatitis). Also, did your doc do a DRE (if not you absolutely should have one)? If so, was it done after the blood draw?

Posts.Title: Considerations for Stepping up from Watchful Waiting

Posts.Content: I was in a similar situation with a small (2-3 mm) nodule on DRE. My PSA was 1.2 which is above average for 40 yrs old but below the typical threshold that would trigger a biopsy. Free PSA was not done and I had never been screened before so I also did not know the velocity. I found these nomograms useful: http://deb.uthscsa.edu/URORiskCalc/Pages/figure.jsp This and other research told me I had a 30-50% chance of having PCa. Biopsy was the right choice for me...

Then my progress plateaued for the next 3-4 weeks before another sudden leap of improvement. Don't over-do the Kegels or you will fatigue the muscles and leak badly! Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Open actually has some other advantages besides just not being pumped full of gas. One of which is ability to have regional (spinal) anesthesia which is less stressful and risky than general and is one of the reasons that I opted for open surgery. I was able to opt for it upon arrival the day of my surgery. I suggest that you ask about ut. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Although PC usually grows slowly, I agree that 4 months seems like a long time to wait to repeat for your peace of mind if nothing else. In the mean time, you should be trying a course of antibiotics probably for a month to rule out the most likely non-PC cause (prostatitis). Also, did your doc do a DRE (if not you absolutely should have one)? If so, was it done after the blood draw?

Free PSA was not done and I had never been screened before so I also did not know the velocity. I found these nomograms useful: http://deb.uthscsa.edu/URORiskCalc/Pages/figure.jsp This and other research told me I had a 30-50% chance of having PCa. Biopsy was the right choice for me...

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: Surgery could be an excellent option for you RTS, but you only get one shot at it so, IMO, its all about finding the most talented surgeon you can as evidenced by hard, objective statistics. You are on the right track with those questions, but need to be more technical and specific in order to be able to objectively interpret the answers: First and foremost, you should as for his positive surgical margin (PSM) rates stratified by pathological stage. I.e. "what are your personal PSM rates for pathological stages pT2 and pT3 respectively?" PSM rates refer to how often the surgeon takes out the prostate but somehow still fails to remove all the cancer. Ideally these rates should be no more than about 2% and 30% for pT2 and pT3 respectively, but you will find that they are often significantly higher even among otherwise good and highly experienced surgeons. You should also ask for his personal rates of return to continence (as well as how he defines continence -- no pads, one "security" pad, etc.) and return of sexual function. You may find that you have to travel to find someone with top statistics and, therefore, maximize your chances of cure and good recovery. If so, I urge you to consider it -- its really no big deal to travel for this operation...

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: Sorry about your diagnosis but welcome, Alpine . The first thing that should be clarified, in case it has not been made clear to you already, is that your stage T3 (clinical stage cT3, to be precise) indicates that your doctor believes the cancer is no longer contained only in the prostate but has already escaped to surrounding structures. This is called extraprostatic extension (EPE). If you had an MRI it likely was seen there but sometimes is determined from biopsy and/or DRE as well. The following link may help you understand your staging (you should look at the left hand column i.e. clinical stages). https://cancerstaging.org/references...stateSmall.pdf Nevertheless, the fact that there has been is no finding of distant metastasis on the bone scan is good news, so there is a still a chance of cure at this point. An important next step is to get a 2nd opinion on your biopsy from an expert (e.g. Johns Hopkins or Bostwick Labs). It is also important to know if your Gleason score is is 3+4 (primarily pattern 3) or 4+3 (primarily pattern 4), but either way you have a number of high risk features and definitely need treatment. Although you will not want to wait too long given your high risk factors, you should still be careful to expore all available options (some of which may require travel) to find the treatment that gives you the absolute best chance for cure. Besides just the choice of the treatment modality itself, with some options -- specifically surgery and Brachytherapy -- the chance of cure is also highly dependent on the skill and experience of the practitioner. The dependence of the experience of the practitioner is less of an issue with external beam radiation. While it is understandable that you may "want this out" (I am a surgery guy and that's how I felt), in your case surgery may really not be the best option as the chance of positive surgical margin (some cancer being left behind) is significant (about 30% or more even with the top surgeons in the world) and even with negative margin adjuvant radiation would probably still be recommended. The incidence and severity of side effects is much higher when radiation an surgery are combined then when either is done alone. If I were you I think I'd want to go get opinions from experts at some national centers of excellence for both high dose rate (HDR) Brachytherapy and low dose rate (LDR) Brachytherapy (i.e. seeds). Both of these allow higher and more uniform dosing within the prostate than external beam ration alone and in a high risk case like yours would likely be combined with external beam to provide treatment to the structures surrounding the prostate and possibly lymph nodes. If you have not done so already I would strongly recommend picking up Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer which explains many of these concepts and the various treatment options. Also, the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center has a nomogram that is very helpful for predicting the probability of various pathology findings if you were to have surgery (even if that is not a modality you would actually choose): http://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/prostate/pre-op Finally, in your case it may be a good idea to begin hormone therapy ASAP to stop the progression while you are considering your options and awaiting treatment. In the case of radiation for high risk cases, neo-adjuvant hormone therapy is often indicated anyways to improve the effectiveness of the radiation by sensitizing the PC cells to radiation.

Posts.Content: Sounds like that could be good news -- like there is a chance that the original diagnosis could have been false-positive, as Epstein did not see enough to make a cancer diagnosis. Did you have the slides sent or the entire blocks? If just the slides, it may be an option to have more slides prepared from the original G block before actually repeating the biopsy. You might inquire with the original pathologist or your uro about that. What percentage of core G tissue was reported as 3+3 cancer in the original?

Posts.Title: Got 2nd opinion from John Hopkins

Posts.Content: My understanding is that PSMs occur frequently at the Apex because the prostate capsule ends in this area and there is no clear division between the gland and the striated sphincter (pelvic floor) muscle. Also according to Dr. Epstein the surgical pathology protocol employed (e.g. shave margin vs perpendicular margin) at the apex can result in false positive margins (artifact as you call it). As Dr. Walsh explains in his book there can be other reasons for false positive surgical margins (e.g. close margins were there were just a thin layer of benign cells over the tumor that get rubbed off from handling between excision and pathology). Capsular incision means that the surgeon inadvertently nicked into the prostate and if tumor was present in the area of the nick this can cause a positive margin even though the tumor was organ-confined (pT2). The term doctors use for this is iatrogenic cause. This happens occasionally to all surgeons but there is significant variation in frequency from the average to good to world class surgeons. The following papers provide more insights on nature and implications of PSMs: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17698141 http://www.archivesofpathology.org/d...65-133.10.1568 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/arti...011-673021.pdf

Posts.Title: My pathology report

Posts.Content: Here are two other good papers: Finley, David S., et al. "Quantitative and qualitative analysis of the recovery of potency after radical prostatectomy: effect of unilateral vs bilateral nerve sparing." BJU international 104.10 (2009): 1484-1489.: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19388985 Ahlering et al. "Overcoming obstacles: nerve-sparing issues in radical prostatectomy." Journal of Endourology 22.4 (200: 745-750.: http://lightburn.weisshospital.com/F...ing%20RARP.pdf "In contrast to common belief, our results demonstrated that preservation of just one nerve will, in the majority of patients, result in similar potency recovery to that with two nerves preserved. Crossover innervation of the one nerve is favored over compensation and hints that techniques that increase nerve volume at the expense of positive surgical margins may need careful introspection" So the good news is that even if the nerves can only be spared on one side, over the long term potency rates still approach those for two-sided nerve sparing due to "crossover innervation", so it may not be worth the extra risk of a positive margin to attempt nerve sparing in an "iffy" case.

Did not have typical diffusion-weighted features of high-grade PCa. No evidence of ECE, NVB, SV or LN involvement. May '13: Open RRP by Dr. Burnett @ Hopkins. Both nerves spared. Posts.Title: A little confused about nerve sparing. What is the criteria?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DNR19598 To begin with I am not interested in hearing all the many reasons there may be for exhausting every treatment there is before "giving up". Please spare me from having to slug through the posts trying to get to the information I'm looking for. I have elected to allow my prostate cancer to run its course. There's more than enough information on what you can do to fight it, how much it will cost, that sort of thing. I'm working towards putting a plan in place that will anticipate all of my "final living needs" (as opposed to "final buring needs"). To this end can anyone share with me what I should expect as the cancer progresses, what things I can do to remain "operational", at what point I'll no longer be "operational", and how long between that occurs and when death occurs? To help you understand, I'm a Crohn's patient and I've been fighting that disease for 35+ years. As a result of disease, surgery, Xrays, secondary infections and the like my prostate is encapsulated in a scar material fortress (they could only get 3 samples, the scar material broke most of the needles). Going in to address the prostate would more than likely total both my rectum and my bladder (cure worse than the disease). Welcome to the forum. Sorry about your situation. More information (PSA history, Gleason score, clinical stage, age) would be very helpful, but even then it is impossible to answer your question conclusively given the highly variable course of PC. Although rarely aggressive disease can kill in only a few years, far more often than not men outlive the disease completely. Your doctors (besides your urologist hopefully you have talked to a medical oncologist who specializes in managing prostate cancer and perhaps a radiation oncologist) should be able to answer these questions better than anyone here. While I can respect your personal decision -- assuming it really is a well-informed one -- to forgo treatment, I do feel compelled to point out (if nothing else, just for the benefit of others similarly situated who may read this thread) that I am puzzled by the rationale you briefly outlined... Depending on your age, PSA and Gleason, it may well be that no treatment would be indicated even if you did not have Crohn's complications. On the other hand if your disease is more aggressive and/or advanced, while I am not an expert on all PC treatments and certainly not at all on Crohn's, I do know that besides radical surgery ("going in to address the prostate") there is a wide array of non- or minimally-invasive treatments with minimal side effects that are appropriate for and routinely given to men with significant commodities. Some (e.g. SBRT, HIFU, focal laser ablation) are potentially curative and others (e.g. hormone therapy, immune therapy) may at least provide anything from brief to indefinite durable remission. It should be understood that the end stages of terminal metastatic PC are notoriously grim and I doubt anyone who truly understands that would really want to hasten its arrival (which hopefully may never occur even without treatment).

Did not have typical diffusion-weighted features of high-grade PCa. No evidence of ECE, NVB, SV or LN involvement. May '13: Open RRP by Dr. Burnett @ Hopkins. Both nerves spared. Final Pathology: GS 3+3, organ confined (tumor extent moderate), SV and 11 nodes all negative (pT2a). Negative margins! Posts.Title: Dying Process with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Here is a good very recent article: http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/777324_1 The author concludes: "With several additional agents that improve prognosis likely to be available in 5 years time, mCRPC will become a chronic illness rather than a terminal diagnosis. The aim, therefore, will be to maintain quality of life and enable men to achieve their own personal goals whilst also improving their overall prognosis."

Posts.Title: Dying Process with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigbrad2008 NJS, how long on average do those notorious/grim terminal signs last. Can the be brought down with narcotics/pain killers/radiation. I'm no expert on this so I don't really know what is typical, but I have seen many accounts of bone pain from full-blown late stage PC being difficult or impossible to control even with the strongest opiates. Prior the half dozen or so drugs that have been developed in the past decade or so that are now routinely sequenced to significantly reduce symptoms / delay progression, I believe that median survival for metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) was only on the order of about one year.

Posts.Content: The decisions of if and to what degree to spare the nerves should usually be made "in-flight" based on look and feel i.e. actual touch with the surgeons finger in the case of open RRP or by observing how the issue responds when poked and tugged with the robot. Any "stickiness" when teasing the nerves away from the prostate can be a sign of cancer having invaded the nerves. However, in the case of high risk features such as aggressive pathology, high-volume or finding of extraprostatic extension on biopsy or MRI, surgeons may sometimes decide up-front not to even attempt on one or both sides for fear of a positive margin. But it is not an all or nothing decision... There are also various "grades" of nerve sparing possible having to do with how close to the prostate the surgeon attempts to get when pealing off the neurovascular bundles. Lower risk disease allows the surgeon to get closer to the prostate and save more nerve while still keeping the chances of a positive surgical margin low. Here are two excellent papers on the topic to read and discuss with your surgeon: Correa JJ, Pow-Sang JM. Optimizing cancer control and functional outcomes following robotic prostatectomy. Cancer Control. 2010 Oct;17(4):233-44.: http://moffitt.org/File%20Library/Ma.../v17n4/233.pdf Tewari et al. Anatomical grades of nerve sparing: a risk-stratified approach to neural-hammock sparing during robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP). BJU Int. 2011;108:984-992: http://www.centerforprostatecancer.o...20Tewari-1.pdf It does appear that your stats (primarily % cancer in the right cores) would support your surgeon's recommendation to not attempt nerve sparing on that side per many of the guidelines in the papers above. However a few questions I would have if I were you: Was my biopsy reading accurate in terns Gleason grades, percentages and PNI? (its hard for me to see how the primary grade of your overall Gleason score is a 4 based on the stats you listed for each core) What percent of the 95% 3+4 core was actually grade 4? Is there any evidence of EPE from biopsy or MRI? If you have not gotten an expert reading of your biopsy and had an MRI, you should discuss both with your doctor given the possible impact on the nerve sparing decision on one hand and risk of positive margins on the other.

Posts.Title: Dying Process with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JMorris271 I do understand the need that a surgeon have the operation experiance but I don't know how to find the right surgeons to ask in the first place. I can't afford to go door to door and inquire about the number of procedures they have performed. I am reading Dr. Walsh's book which I find very good so far and am trying to become as informed as possible about PC and be able to ask the right questions and understand the answers in return. Even if I were to go to Duke or JH,, how do I know whom to start asking My problem is not about PC knowledge but rather how to find the right professional to help me. You would probably be in excellent hands with any of the experienced prostatectomy surgeons at Hopkins including Partin, Carter, Han, Schaeffer, Pavlovich and Bivalacqua. You can find their bios and contact info here: http://urology.jhu.edu/about/faculty.php But, as far as my own specific experience, I set up a consult with Dr Allaf, head of robotic surgery, who had personally responded to my initial email within a few hours. I was very impressed with him, his experience and outcome statistics. And when I asked him during the consult about the trade-offs of robotic vs. traditional open RRP he was very unbiased and went out of his way to arrange an impromptu consult with Dr. Burnett who was very gracious and also extremely impressive (3000+ surgeries under his belt with world class outcome statistics). I ultimately opted for open surgery with Dr. Burnett and I feel very fortunate because he ended up encountering some unexpected difficulties due to prior mesh hernia repair that doubled the time of my operation and that he later told me would probably have caused most surgeons (including some of his colleagues at Hopkins) to abort the procedure, but he stuck with me and I got an excellent outcome. He has been terrific ever since as well (much easier to contact and more responsive any any of my local doctors). Aside from the docs at Hopkins, Ash Tewari at Mount Sinai in NY City is a pioneering innovator who has published unrivaled outcome statistics and I have corresponded with a couple of guys who selected him and said that beyond his surgical prowess he really exceeded their expectations with his graciousness as well.

Posts.Title: How to researh

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JMorris271 One point that resonates with me is to find the best surgeon, Rad/oncol possible. I'm at a loss of how to go about that. With no contacts in medical circles or first hand knowledge of my areas talent. Does anyone have suggestions on where I can begin researching and rating my doctor options? Pubmed is a good place to start assuming you you are comfortable interpreting medical journal papers. An abstract is almost always available and sometimes also full text for free or, if not, usually for purchase. Back when I was diagnosed ~18 months ago I spent a lot of time searching for surgeons with the best published results (in terms of surgical margin rates). I put together a spreadsheet summarizing the data, but has not been updated in over a year: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets...it?usp=sharing

Posts.Title: How to researh

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bob_R The surgeon seems to be dead keen on surgery and my initial thought are this is the way to go, untill I read about the side effects which are terifying to be frank. Given I am an active and fit middle aged man with a very active sex life I am trying to appreciate just how much of a lifestyle change this will mean. Hi and welcome Bob, Depending on your detailed stats, you probably have multiple good options you should explore. Take your time (you can't / shouldn't have surgery for at least 6-8 weeks after biopsy) to talk to multiple doctors and consider all the treatment options (including both robotic and open surgery, external beam radiation, and LDR and HDR brachytherapy) . If you are inclined towards surgery, seek out the best surgeons, which may mean traveling. As Patrick Walsh, the father of nerve-sparing prostatectomy, wrote in his book, "Radical Prostatectomy is a tricky operation, one of the most difficult in medicine". To improve your chance of a good outcome you will want to find a surgeon who is both highly-experienced (1000+ surgeries) and highly-talented as evidenced by their personal outcome statistics -- first and foremost positive surgical margin (PSM) rates, which are the likelihood of them failing to get all the cancer out. PSM rates for patients with cancer that has not spread beyond the prostate in the hands of a good surgeon are 6%-8% but for the same patients in the hands of the very best surgeons they are below 2%. While the potential side effects of surgery are scary, assuming you are a candidate for nerve sparing, at your young age and in the hands of a skilled surgeon your long-term prospects are excellent! I am 40 and had open surgery by a "virtuoso" less than 10 weeks ago. I am now down to one pad per day, which sometimes stays dry; erections began to return at 6 weeks with Cialis and, as of this week, are good enough for sex. Here is a link to a post detailing my pre-op decision process, which may be of interest to you: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...015#post191015

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bob_R The surgeon seems to be dead keen on surgery and my initial thought are this is the way to go, untill I read about the side effects which are terifying to be frank. Given I am an active and fit middle aged man with a very active sex life I am trying to appreciate just how much of a lifestyle change this will mean. Hi and welcome Bob, Depending on your detailed stats, you probably have multiple good options you should explore. Take your time (you can't / shouldn't have surgery for at least 6-8 weeks after biopsy) to talk to multiple doctors and consider all the treatment options (including both robotic and open surgery, external beam radiation, and LDR and HDR brachytherapy) . If you are inclined towards surgery, seek out the best surgeons, which may mean traveling. As Patrick Walsh, the father of nerve-sparing prostatectomy, wrote in his book, "Radical Prostatectomy is a tricky operation, one of the most difficult in medicine". To improve your chance of a good outcome you will want to find a surgeon who is both highly-experienced (1000+ surgeries) and highly-talented as evidenced by their personal outcome statistics -- first and foremost positive surgical margin (PSM) rates, which are the likelihood of them failing to get all the cancer out. PSM rates for patients with cancer that has not spread beyond the prostate in the hands of a good surgeon are 6%-8% but for the same patients in the hands of the very best surgeons they are below 2%. While the potential side effects of surgery are scary, assuming you are a candidate for nerve sparing, at your young age and in the hands of a skilled surgeon your long-term prospects are excellent! I am 40 and had open surgery by a "virtuoso" less than 10 weeks ago. I am now down to one pad per day, which sometimes stays dry; erections began to return at 6 weeks with Cialis and, as of this week, are good enough for sex. Posts.Title: Just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Greetings Omegaman. Sorry you have to join our club. Based on your stats, your PC would be categorized as intermediate risk and it definitely needs to be treated. Still, you should take your time and consider all your options: robotic surgery, open surgery, LDR brachy (seeds), HDR brachy, external beam radiation (e.g. SBRT, IMRT). All have advantages and disadvantages. And you should talk to multiple doctors, including a medical oncologist who specializes in PC. A second opinion on your biopsy from an expert like Epstein or Bostwick would also be highly recommended ASAP. With surgery and brachy it is particularly critical that you seek out a practitioner who is BOTH highly experienced AND highly skilled as evidenced by their personal statistics (e.g. positive surgical margin rates for surgeons). This may mean traveling, but you only have one shot to get it right! Regarding the MRI being suspicions for capsular involvement this is particularly concerning. Although it is not factored in to the D'Amico risk stratification and the reliability of MRI for prostate cancer remains somewhat controversial, there is pretty good evidence that when an MRI shows extra capsular extension (ECE) that it is usually correct. While surgery can still be a effective in the setting of ECE, this may be a reason to consider brachytherapy (potentially in combination with external beam radiation) as your primary therapy instead of surgery. While if surgery fails you would still have radiation as salvage therapy, the side effect profile for salvage radiation is considerably worse than when you have it as primary. If you are inclined towards surgery, you should strongly consider open surgery, which some feel is better in cases of palpable (cT2) disease like yours and mine. See the following brief video by a world class doctor at Johns Hopkins who does both open and robotic procedures: Open or Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery -- Which is Right for You? Regarding partial nerve sparing, with your risk factors the surgeon you talked with is on the right track with this, although, as explained below, "approx 80-90%" sounds like it may not be nearly conservative enough. Nerve sparing is done primarily by "look and feel". In open surgery they can palpate directly on the gland to feel for tumor near the edge. With robotic they can poke and tug the tissue and watch to see if it looks stiff or soft. In both open and robotic they observe how easily the NVB releases from the prostate (it should fall away easily with any "stickiness" being a red flag). But because this look and feel is not infallible for detecting all ECE, there have also been guidelines developed based on pre-op risk criteria to pre-plan how much nerve sparing is safe to attempt. E.g.: www.moffittcancercenter.com/CCJRoot/v17n4/pdf/233.pdf onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1464-410X.2011.10565.x/pdf It seems that your stats put you at high risk for nerve sparing by most of these guidelines and suggest that only minimal or no nerve sparing should be attempted on the right side. Because I had palpable tumor with perineural invasion I was very concerned about the possibility of ECE. This is one of the reasons I selected open surgery and because of the cT2, my surgeon decided before hand to only attempt partial (extra-fascial) nerve sparing (which he was able to do successfully) on the right side. I also elected to have an MRI with the mindset that if it was negative for ECE I would take that with a grain of salt but if it was suspicious for ECE I would probably want to skip any attempt at nerve sparing on the right side knowing that thanks to crossover innervation in the longer term potency for unilateral nerve sparing approaches that for bilateral (see Ahlering J Endourol. 2008) and that, in any event, ED is virtually always treatable through one modality or another. Here is a link to my detailed post on my decision process, which may be of interest to you: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...015#post191015 Finally, I would strongly recommend picking up a copy of Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Title: New to this: clinical T2 prostate cancer Gleason 3+4 = 7/10 and 3+3 = 6/10

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JMorris271 I do understand the need that a surgeon have the operation experiance but I don't know how to find the right surgeons to ask in the first place. I can't afford to go door to door and inquire about the number of procedures they have performed. I am reading Dr. Walsh's book which I find very good so far and am trying to become as informed as possible about PC and be able to ask the right questions and understand the answers in return. Even if I were to go to Duke or JH,, how do I know whom to start asking My problem is not about PC knowledge but rather how to find the right professional to help me. You would probably be in excellent hands with any of the experienced prostatectomy surgeons at Hopkins including Partin, Carter, Han, Schaeffer, Pavlovich and Bivalacqua. You can find their bios and contact info here: http://urology.jhu.edu/about/faculty.php But, as far as my own specific experience, I set up a consult with Dr Allaf, head of robotic surgery, who had personally responded to my initial email within a few hours. I was very impressed with him, his experience and outcome statistics. And when I asked him during the consult about the trade-offs of robotic vs. traditional open RRP he was very unbiased and went out of his way to arrange an impromptu consult with Dr. Burnett who was very gracious and also extremely impressive (3000+ surgeries under his belt with world class outcome statistics). I ultimately opted for open surgery with Dr. Burnett and I feel very fortunate because he ended up encountering some unexpected difficulties due to prior mesh hernia repair that doubled the time of my operation and that he later told me would probably have caused most surgeons (including some of his colleagues at Hopkins) to abort the procedure, but he stuck with me and I got an excellent outcome. He has been terrific ever since as well (much easier to contact and more responsive any any of my local doctors). Aside from the docs at Hopkins, Ash Tewari at Mount Sinai in NY City is a pioneering innovator who has published unrivaled outcome statistics and I have corresponded with a couple of guys who selected him and said that beyond his surgical prowess he really exceeded their expectations with his graciousness as well.

Posts.Content: Greetings Omegaman. Sorry you have to join our club. Based on your stats, your PC would be categorized as intermediate risk and it definitely needs to be treated. Still, you should take your time and consider all your options: robotic surgery, open surgery, LDR brachy (seeds), HDR brachy, external beam radiation (e.g. SBRT, IMRT). All have advantages and disadvantages. And you should talk to multiple doctors, including a medical oncologist who specializes in PC. A second opinion on your biopsy from an expert like Epstein or Bostwick would also be highly recommended ASAP. With surgery and brachy it is particularly critical that you seek out a practitioner who is BOTH highly experienced AND highly skilled as evidenced by their personal statistics (e.g. positive surgical margin rates for surgeons). This may mean traveling, but you only have one shot to get it right! Regarding the MRI being suspicions for capsular involvement this is particularly concerning. Although it is not factored in to the D'Amico risk stratification and the reliability of MRI for prostate cancer remains somewhat controversial, there is pretty good evidence that when an MRI shows extra capsular extension (ECE) that it is usually correct. While surgery can still be a effective in the setting of ECE, this may be a reason to consider brachytherapy (potentially in combination with external beam radiation) as your primary therapy instead of surgery. While if surgery fails you would still have radiation as salvage therapy, the side effect profile for salvage radiation is considerably worse than when you have it as primary. If you are inclined towards surgery, you should strongly consider open surgery, which some feel is better in cases of palpable (cT2) disease like yours and mine. See the following brief video by a world class doctor at Johns Hopkins who does both open and robotic procedures: Open or Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery -- Which is Right for You? Regarding partial nerve sparing, with your risk factors the surgeon you talked with is on the right track with this, although, as explained below, "approx 80-90%" sounds like it may not be nearly conservative enough. Nerve sparing is done primarily by "look and feel". In open surgery they can palpate directly on the gland to feel for tumor near the edge. With robotic they can poke and tug the tissue and watch to see if it looks stiff or soft. In both open and robotic they observe how easily the NVB releases from the prostate (it should fall away easily with any "stickiness" being a red flag). But because this look and feel is not infallible for detecting all ECE, there have also been guidelines developed based on pre-op risk criteria to pre-plan how much nerve sparing is safe to attempt. E.g.: www.moffittcancercenter.com/CCJRoot/v17n4/pdf/233.pdf onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1464-410X.2011.10565.x/pdf It seems that your stats put you at high risk for nerve sparing by most of these guidelines and suggest that only minimal or no nerve sparing should be attempted on the right side. Because I had palpable tumor with perineural invasion I was very concerned about the possibility of ECE. This is one of the reasons I selected open surgery and because of the cT2, my surgeon decided before hand to only attempt partial (extra-fascial) nerve sparing (which he was able to do successfully) on the right side. I also elected to have an MRI with the mindset that if it was negative for ECE I would take that with a grain of salt but if it was suspicious for ECE I would probably want to skip any attempt at nerve sparing on the right side knowing that thanks to crossover innervation in the longer term potency for unilateral nerve sparing approaches that for bilateral (see Ahlering J Endourol. 2008) and that, in any event, ED is virtually always treatable through one modality or another. Here is a link to my detailed post on my decision process, which may be of interest to you: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...015#post191015 Finally, I would strongly recommend picking up a copy of Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer.
Posts.Signature: Jan '13: PSA 1.23, small nodule on DRE (1st screening @ age 40) Mar '13: Biopsy 2/12 cores positive GS 3+3: rt mid 10% and rt apex 20% w/ PNI+ Stage cT2a Apr '13: Biopsy confirmed by Dr. Epstein @ Hopkins May '13: eMRI: lesion imaged in rt mid and apex (but not most inferior apex). Did not have typical diffusion-weighted features of high-grade PCa. No evidence of ECE, NVB, SV or LN involvement. May '13: Open RRP by Dr. Burnett @ Hopkins. Both nerves spared. Final Pathology: GS 3+3, organ confined (tumor extent moderate), SV and 11 nodes all negative (pT2a). Negative margins! Post-op PSA: 0.01 @ 6wk, <0.01 @ 21wk, 0.01 @ 17mo, 0.01 @ 30mo http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...t-op-(my-story)

Posts.Title: Da Vinci Complete

Posts.Content: Clinical stage "cT2" (not to be confused with pathologic stage, which can only be assigned after surgery) is based on a tumor being palpable on DRE. This does not rule out the tumor having left the prostate ("extracapsular extension" or ECE) but unless there is actually evidence of ECE (which could be from DRE, imaging or biopsy) you would not be assigned a higher clinical stage than cT2. See https://cancerstaging.org/references...stateSmall.pdf Some men who are clinical stage cT2 will end up being pathologic stage pT3 or, less commonly, even pT4 after surgery: You can use the MSK PCa nomogram (http://nomograms.mskcc.org/Prostate/PreTreatment.aspx) or Partin tables (http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/partintables.php) to predict the likelihood of this occurring based on your stats.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Chiefmoose Hey just found out a few days ago I have prostate cancer. Waiting to get a bone scan then start radiation treatments and some kind of shots. Can anyone help me as to what to expect and how deadly is it please? Didn't get much info yet from my doctor. Not sure if I should just have it removed or go with the radiation. Any help will be appreciated Thanks Sorry to hear about your diagnosis Moose, but welcome to the forum. It would be helpful to know the details of your case. In particular: Your age PSA DRE findings / clinical stage (e.g. T1c, T2a, T2b, T2c, T3) Gleason score (e.g. 3+3=6, 3+4=7, 4+3=7, 4+4=8, 4+5=9) Number of biopsy cores positive for cancer Total number of biopsy cores taken Percentages of cancer in positive cores If your doctor didn't provide these details, you should call and ask for them and be sure to obtain a full copy of your biopsy report. You should also think about having your biopsy slides sent out for an expert 2nd opinion (e.g. from Johns Hopkins or Bostwick labs). It is not uncommon to have your Gleason score change up or down upon expert review. Finally, I would recommend that one of the first things you do is get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. It does a great job explaining the disease and various treatments.

Posts.Title: Just Found Out

Posts.Content: Part 4/4: Other surgeons I considered: Thomas Ahlering, UC Irvine: Dr. Ahlering is a heavily-published pioneer of RALP who has introduced several refinements of surgical approach and other innovations (e.g. transrectal cooling device to reduce operative trauma to nerves and urethral sphincter). He specializes exclusively in prostatectomy vs. other urologic surgeries and, as I understand it, limits his volume to one or two surgeries per day explicitly to avoid rushing / cutting corners but still has around 1300 under his belt. I really liked that he seems to be heavily focused on optimizing oncologic outcomes and had published PSM rates of 3.1% and 18% for pT2 and pT3 respectively for his 251st through 750th patients. Although he appeared to be one of the 2-3 most impressive RALP surgeons in the world, I pushed him down on my list because Irvine would have been a pretty long haul with no direct flights (not great for returning home post-op). Apparently he would have done a telephone consult, which would have been convenient, but I never needed to pursue. Ash Tewari, Cornell: Dr. Tewari is another heavily-published RALP pioneer known for driving improvements in surgical approach. He recently published PSM rates of 2.1% and 33% for pT2 and pT3 respectively for 209 patients using his latest surgical innovation (“retro-apical technique”). Although he also appeared to be one of the 2-3 most impressive RALP surgeons in the world, I pushed him down on my list because I was not too comfortable with the idea of leaving my wife to fend for herself in NYC while I was in the hospital. I never needed to pursue a consultation. Peter Scardino and James Eastham, Memorial Sloan-Kettering: I initially considered both doctors due to their excellent reputations and extensive experience with open RRP. However I was not too enthusiastic about having my surgery in New York and I found their published PSM rates on a series of 692 patients (5.3% and 24% for pT2 and pT3 respectively) to be significantly higher than those of other doctors on my list. Mani Menon, Vattikuti Institute; Vipul Patel, Global Robotics Institute Florida: I initially considered both doctors due to their extensive experience with RALP. Also Vattikuti was appealing because it would have been a very short trip for me. On the other hand I was not really comfortable with the high daily surgical volume (especially in the case of Patel, who I understand may do a half dozen or more). Ultimately I ruled out both because when I researched their surgical margin rates (i.e. anywhere from 4%- 10% for pT2 depending on which published series) I concluded they may not be any better than I could get at home. Robert Nadler, Northwestern: I included Dr. Nadler in my list because in 2010 he published PSM rates of 2.5% and 28% for pT2 and pT3 respectively for 95 patients using a modified RALP technique (i.e. staple ligation of dorsal venous complex). While these numbers are quite good, they are from a relatively small series. Also, a cursory search revealed a significant number of less-than-stellar patient reviews that made me extremely wary. I never pursued a consultation.

Posts.Title: Just Found Out

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that the disease is present throughout much of the prostate, JD. Nevertheless, your stats only put you in the "intermediate risk" category. Your two PSAs actually straddle the breakpoint of the Partin tables so the likelihood of your lymph nodes being clean is somewhere between 91-96% assuming your clinical stage was cT2b or cT2c. If you opt for surgery, in the hands of a top surgeon your chance of negative margins is probably at least 80% or better (>90% for pT2 and >70% for pT3+ with about 50/50 chance of either). Talking to your friends is fine for a start, but I cannot stress enough the importance of finding a highly experienced surgeon with a proven track record of very low surgical margin rates. You only have one shot at this. You can certainly also explore other options (seeds, HDR, SBRT, etc.) that could also offer an excellent chance of cure with different side effect profiles compared to surgery. Good luck!
