Posts.Title: Path report post surgery

Posts.Content: The second opinion from the MD Anderson radiaologist is certainly encouraging news. Assuming the first bone scan was done with common T99 radionuclide another option besides just a third opinion on the original scan would be to obtain a new scan using a more sensitive technology such as F18 PET scan or C11 Acetate PET scan: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3129631/ Here is some info on the TNM clinical staging system: http://www.mskcc.org/term/1997-uuic-...ystem-prostate Metastasis status is reflected in by M0, M1 or Mx. The T field is independent of metastasis and is based on what the doctor feels on DRE. Here is a useful predictive nomogram from Memorial Sloan-Kettering: http://nomograms.mskcc.org/Prostate/PreTreatment.aspx Since two of the three labs (including the most recent) had the PSA at 44 I would probably use that or, to be more conservative, you could use the average value of 50. You would enter 3 for Primary Gleason Grade and 4 for Secondary Gleason Grade. Then you will need to enter the clinical T stage. Just for example, if it was T2a (tumor palpable in one lobe on DRE) you get the following results... Organ Confined Disease 37% Extracapsular Extension 64% Seminal Vesicle Invasion 27% Lymph Node Involvement 10.9% Progression Free Probability after Radical Prostatectomy @ 5 Year 64% Progression Free Probability after Radical Prostatectomy @ 10 Year 51% Probability of Cancer-Specific Survival after Radical Prostatectomy @ 10 Year 99% Probability of Cancer-Specific Survival after Radical Prostatectomy @ 15 Year 99% Another good one is the Han pre-operative table: http://urology.jhu.edu/prostate/han_tables.php?lk=Han Which predicts the following assuming T2a... Probability of Biochemical Recurrence (detectable PSA level) at: 3 years after surgery: 13% 5 years after surgery: 20% 7 years after surgery: 28% 10 years after surgery: 35% So... while your husband is clearly a high risk patient, as long as he has no proven mets he still has a realistic chance of a cure and an excellent likelihood of being around to see your kids grow up. Besides surgery there are other treatments that could be good (or perhaps better) options for him such as brachytherapy and external beam radiation. Besides surgeons and radiation oncologists it may also be helpful to talk to a medical oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer. With your husband's high risk status, relatively young age and having so much to live for, I couldn't agree more with Chuck's advice to seek the absolute best treatment possible from the most experienced & qualified doctors and MD Anderson is a great option. Although I was much lower risk, I decided to travel for surgery and it was really no big deal. Finally, I would highly recommend obtaining a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer, which does a great job of explaining these and other topics and I found to be invaluable.

Posts.Title: Conflicting diagnosis! Now what?

Posts.Content: It understandable why seeing an increase would concern you, but don't panic... .02 is 10x less than the typically accepted threshold of 0.2 for declaring recurrence and considering salvage radiation and there are a couple other possible explanations for this less insidious than your cancer recurring: 1) Possible measurement noise / error. You could ask to have the test repeated to see if it comes back .02 again. 2) Insignificant biochemical recurrence (iBCR) due to bits of benign prostate being left behind (as discussed in this recent post: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...l=1#post263673) You mentioned it was ".01" last year. Was that 0.01 or <0.01 (undetectable)? Also, what was it in prior years?

Posts.Content: Hi Jacakay. I'm sorry to hear of your huband's diagnosis, but I welcome you. You mentioned 4 PSA values. Given the high levels I assume these were all taken over a short time period vs. several years. Was prostatitis ever ruled out via a course of antibiotics or by culturing the biopsy cores? Also do you know the cliical stage from DRE (i.e. T1c, T2a, T2b, T2c, T3a, T3b, or T3c)?

Posts.Title: Conflicting diagnosis! Now what?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by hopper Hello This is my first post. Age 59. PSA of 4.7 on 9/14/2014, PSA of 6.3 on 11/12/2014. Urologist performed DRE and said slightly enlarged but was fairly confident that nothing would be found in a biopsy. Biopsy performed on 12/16/2014. 12 samples, 5 benign 7 positive with the highest being 3+4=7 in 2 cores. the rest were 3+3=6. Cancer seems to be confined to prostate. Negative bone scan. He suggested RP but also gave me a brochure to Cyberknife (SBRT). I did a lot of reading and decided to go with the Cyberknife until I had my appointment to talk with the Oncologist. The Dr. said he was surprised that I would consider it over surgery considering my age and my cancer being considered of medium risk. He also said that he would want to do HT for about a year. The HT was nothing I had considered. I read up on the side effects and I talked with the wife and grown Daughter and they both said I was moody enough and depressed enough already(which is true) to have the HT. I called the Dr. and asked if I could do the SBRT without the HT. He said I could but strongly advised against it. I thought OK I will have the surgery. I then talked to my Urologist and told him this and he didn't understand why the oncologist would not want me to do it without the HT saying that the cancer was on the low side of medium risk. He also said he would do the surgery without the HT. BTW both DR.s have very good reputations and several awards in their fields and I researched them both and found no bad reviews. Sorry for the babbling but just going a bit nuts trying to decide which way to go. So if anyone has any comments I would sure appreciate it Sorry about your diagnosis but welcome, hopper. It is fairly common to use neoadjuvant hormone therapy prior to radiation to sensitize the cancer cells to the radiation and make it more effective, but I've never heard of having to do it for a year. There is not generally considered to be a similar benefit to neoadjuvant HT prior to surgery, so that makes sense. SBRT and surgery both seem like potentially good options for you although SBRT is newer and does not have the same long term results available. Surgery provides more conclusive data on your disease state, which may give peace of mind, but the outcomes with surgery are MUCH more dependent on the skill and experience of the specific practitioner than they are with external beam radiation. Prostatectomy is any extremely delicate and challenging procedure -- even when done roboticly. It takes many hundreds (some studies suggest well over 1000) surgeries for a surgeon to optimize his technique. And experience is necessary but not sufficient. The few best surgeons in the world seem to have a unique talent that allows them to significantly outperform by objective measures most other equally experienced surgeons. A key such measure of effectiveness in achieving cure through surgery is the positive surgical margin (PSM) rate, which is a measure of how often the surgeon leaves some cancer behind. In particular I recommend you look at a surgeon's PSM rate for pathological organ-confined (pT2) disease. As shown in the following a spreadsheet, world-class PSM rates for pT2 patients are <2% but many other well-known and highly-experienced surgeons actually have PSM rates several times higher than that: http://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/...it?usp=sharing So I'd encourage you to ask your urologist for his personal stats. And how you ask the questions is very important so that you can compare apples-to-apples. Specifically you should ask: "What is your positive surgical margin rate for pathalogic stage T2 (stage pT2) patients?" "What is your positive surgical margin rate for pathalogic stage T3 (stage pT3) patients?" If the answers are significantly higher than 2% and 35% respectively (particularly if the PSM rate for stage pT2 is much more than 2%), then you can probably significantly improve your chances by going elsewhere. And many guys travel for this procedure, so don't let that deter you -- you only get one shot at this! Have you considered low dose rate Brachytherapy (i.e. seeds)? It is a simple procedure with low side effects and high effectiveness since it allows higher and more uniform dosing throughout the prostate compared to external beam radiation. However a downside, like surgery, is that the effectiveness is more sensitive to the skill of the individual practitioner. If you have not done so already I would strongly recommend picking up Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer which explains many of these concepts and the various treatment options.

Posts.Content: Sorry about your diagnosis JD1969, but welcome and don't panic! I know how you feel. I am 40 with 2 young kids and was just diagnosed in March had surgery in May and am now doing very well. Here is post with the details if your are interested: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...t-op-(my-story) A good thing to do this weekend would be to pick up a copy of Patrick Walsh's book Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer and definitely be sure to get a copy of your path report on Mon. When you have questions we'll be here to help...

Posts.Title: 38 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear the bx results Gideon, but glad to hear you are going straight to a center of excellence and getting a 2nd opinion on the slides. That is the right thing to do to stack the odds in your favor. In parallel you may want to consider lining up more appointments with additional experts. I talked to six top surgeons and gleaned something useful from every consult. In your case you should be talking with surgeons, radiation oncologists and medical oncologists who specialize in PC. It would be helpful if you could share your additional stats (PSA, clinical stage, % of positive tissue in cores). Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by September Hello - It is w/ deep regret that I have to be here. No offense. Hubby has been dx w/ Pca. It's not good. I have been reading and researching myself. Hubby doesn't surf the web. I will fill in the information I have on hand as soon as I figure out how to do it. Hubby goes faithfully to his doctor yearly. He is 60. His Dad had Pca at 60 also. He did not die from it. Psa was 5.3. Up from last year of 3.1. Saw urilogist, he did biopsy. Six out of twelve spots were positive. All scans came back good. Appt. today with uroligist. He is referring him to the specialist to see if he is a candidate for surgery via robotic. Grade was HIGH End. Staging T1C. Gleason 4+4. Bilateral. I bought the Walsh book today. Scared out of my gord. How bad is this? Lay it on me. Hello September. Sorry about your husband's diagnosis, but welcome. You will find lots of help and advice here. Its normal to feel like you do but try to just take a deep breath. While Gleason 8 is aggressive PC and puts you husband in the high-risk category but the big piture considering his other statistics (stage T1c and 5.3 PSA) provide plenty of hope... According to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering pre-treatment nomogram your husband has a 63% chance of organ-confined disease. Specifically it says that he has a 67% chance of no extra capsular extension, a 92% chance of no Seminal Vesicle Invasion and a 96% chance of no lymph node involvement. The Partin Tables predict very similar numbers. The MSK nomogram also predicts that at 10 years following successful surgery he has an 85% chance of no detectable disease and a 98% chance of not having died of PC. So I would view that as excellent news. But the key point here is successful surgery, which is less common that you may think. In the best case scenario of disease confined to the prostate ("horses have not left the barn"), most good surgeons will still have about an 8% or higher chance of leaving some of it behind (a positive surgical margin or "PSM"). If you consider surgery I would strongly urge you to seek out these top surgeons. You only get on shot at this. There are also other viable treatments (brachytherapy and/or external beam radiation with adjuvant hormone blockade) that can offer a good chance of cure. Reading the Walsh book is a great start to understanding his disease and options. If you have more questions we are here to help. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank Given your numbers I would be very hesitant about jumping into surgery (njs has pointed out what the numbers more than likely mean), as some type of radiation more than likely would follow the surgery - unless the PCa is 100% confined. Blank -- I think you are overstating the likelihood of radiation for September's husband given his stats. It is true that adjuvant radiation would be indicated as an option in the event of non-organ confined disease (extracapsular extension, SV invasion and/or LN involvement) but according to the MSK nonogram there is only a 37% chance of non-organ confined disease. Adjuvant radiation would also be indicated in the event of organ confined disease with a positive margin, but in the best surgical hands this would add about 4% to the 37%, so still well less than 50/50. And that is the predicted likelihood of adjuvant radiation being offered as an option. It is optional because, while there is evidence that early adjuvant radiation offers modest benefits vs. later salvage radiation, the patient may elect to forego it and its side effects and only do radiation as salvage therapy if and when there is actual evidence of local recurrence. For patients with these stats not needing or electing adjuvant radiation, the likelihood of salvage radiation would be at most 15% at 10 years based on the 85% prediction of progression free survival.

Posts.Title: Newbie's wife.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank Given your numbers I would be very hesitant about jumping into surgery (njs has pointed out what the numbers more than likely mean), as some type of radiation more than likely would follow the surgery - unless the PCa is 100% confined. Blank -- I think you are overstating the likelihood of radiation for September's husband given his stats. It is true that adjuvant radiation would be indicated as an option in the event of non-organ confined disease (extracapsular extension, SV invasion and/or LN involvement) but according to the MSK nonogram there is only a 37% chance of non-organ confined disease. Adjuvant radiation would also be indicated in the event of organ confined disease with a positive margin, but in the best surgical hands this would add about 4% to the 37%, so still well less than 50/50. And that is the predicted likelihood of adjuvant radiation being offered as an option. It is optional because, while there is evidence that early adjuvant radiation offers modest benefits vs. later salvage radiation, the patient may elect to forego it and its side effects and only do radiation as salvage therapy if and when there is actual evidence of local recurrence. For patients with these stats not needing or electing adjuvant radiation, the likelihood of salvage radiation would be at most 15% at 10 years based on the 85% prediction of progression free survival.

Posts.Title: Newbie's wife.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by September Hello - It is w/ deep regret that I have to be here. No offense. Hubby has been dx w/ Pca. It's not good. I have been reading and researching myself. Hubby doesn't surf the web. I will fill in the information I have on hand as soon as I figure out how to do it. Hubby goes faithfully to his doctor yearly. He is 60. His Dad had Pca at 60 also. He did not die from it. Psa was 5.3. Up from last year of 3.1. Saw urilogist, he did biopsy. Six out of twelve spots were positive. All scans came back good. Appt. today with uroligist. He is referring him to the specialist to see if he is a candidate for surgery via robotic. Grade was HIGH End. Staging T1C. Gleason 4+4. Bilateral. I bought the Walsh book today. Scared out of my gord. How bad is this? Lay it on me. Hello September. Sorry about your husband's diagnosis, but welcome. You will find lots of help and advice here. Its normal to feel like you do but try to just take a deep breath. While Gleason 8 is aggressive PC and puts you husband in the high-risk category but the big piture considering his other statistics (stage T1c and 5.3 PSA) provide plenty of hope... According to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering pre-treatment nomogram your husband has a 63% chance of organ-confined disease. Specifically it says that he has a 67% chance of no extra capsular extension, a 92% chance of no Seminal Vesicle Invasion and a 96% chance of no lymph node involvement. The Partin Tables predict very similar numbers. The MSK nomogram also predicts that at 10 years following successful surgery he has an 85% chance of no detectable disease and a 98% chance of not having died of PC. So I would view that as excellent news. But the key point here is successful surgery, which is less common that you may think. In the best case scenario of disease confined to the prostate ("horses have not left the barn"), most good surgeons will still have about an 8% or higher chance of leaving some of it behind (a positive surgical margin or "PSM"). But there are a handfull of top surgeons (e.g. many at Johns Hopkins, Ash Tewari at Cornell, Tomas Ahlering at UC Irvine) who can offer your husband PSM rates of 2% or below. If you consider surgery I would strongly urge you to seek out these top surgeons. You only get on shot at this. There are also other viable treatments (brachytherapy and/or external beam radiation with adjuvant hormone blockade) that can offer a good chance of cure. Reading the Walsh book is a great start to understanding his disease and options. If you have more questions we are here to help. Good luck!

Posts.Title: 12 core biopsy samples 1/1000 of the prostate, What does that mean

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the positive margin, but PSMs at the apex are fairly common and it is good news that it is only GS3+3. This does not indicate aggressive cancer. To be clear, the report does not mean that there is any uncertainty about the PSM -- they are certain that there was a 3mm long PSM. The uncertainty is only whether the PSM was caused by the cancer growing outside the prostate or by the surgeon cutting into the prostate. Unlike most of the prostate, at the apex there is no capsule clearly separating the prostate from extra-prostatic tissue (in this case the striated sphincter muscles). Studies show that the specific Gleason score of the tumor at the PSM location predicts likelihood of recurrence. PSMs that were only GS3+3 are less likely to cause recurrence (presumably because the GS3+3 is more likely to die off in the aftermath of the surgery). Moreover, studies show that, even if it does eventually result in a recurrence, GS3+3 is virtually always curable by salvage radiation.

Posts.Title: Need help interpreting this positive margin ! Please help !

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gearloose Question : Negative surgical margins good or bad? Walsh book states men with negative margins less likely to benefit from RT. Negative surgical margins are GOOD. This means the pathologist saw no evidence of cancer left behind in the prostate bed (which is called a positive margin). Men with negative margins are less likely to have PSA recurrence after surgery (and therefore to need potential radiation therapy in the first place) compared to men with positive margins. However when men with negative margins do experience PSA recurrence, radiation therapy is less likely to be effective (compared to men with positive margins) because with negative margins the the cancer is is less likely to be recurring locally in the prostate bed where it can be cured by radiation therapy.

Posts.Title: 12 core biopsy samples 1/1000 of the prostate, What does that mean

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I've read this term (1/1000) before. What does 1/1000 mean. Does it mean with each core that is taken there is only a chance of hitting the cancer 1 in 1000. No, it doesn't work that way. The chance of hitting the cancer depends mostly on the percentage of prostate that contains cancer. For example, if the tumor is 10% of the prostate, then a single core has around 10% chance (actually a little more because the core has length vs being a single point) of hitting tumor or about a 90% chance of missing. But a 2nd core has another more-or-less independent 10% chance of hitting the cancer. For cancer involving 10% of the prostate the chances of all 12 cores missing tumor (false negative) would be 0.9 ^12 = 28% or about a 72% chance of finding it.

Posts.Title: Shorter penis after prostate removal?

Posts.Content: I have heard that this is a potential side effect due to pulling the urethra up toward the bladder to fill the "gap" where the prostate was. It was listed as a possible side effect on my consent form. That said, I have to say if anything I'm longer than pre-op in the non-erect state (maybe that's just the Cialis) and I seem no different than pre-op when hard. My prostate was small so not much gap to fill I guess.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jimmie webb should radiation be done when psa reading is 0.20 or before 0.20 . my cancer is recurring after 22 year. Hi and welcome, Jimmie. Why do you think your cancer is recurring? As Chuck indicated, it would be helpful to have your stats from surgery (final Gleason score, pathologic stage, margin status, etc.) and PSA history. From your question on PSA, I assume it is rising but not yet at 0.2, which, to answer you question, is the lowest level at which consideration of salvage radiation is recommended according to the latest joint guidance from the American Urological Association and the American Society for Radiation Oncology (see http://www.auanet.org/common/pdf/edu...statectomy.pdf). And if the only indication of potential recurrence is a modest PSA rise after 22 long years, there are other possible explanations for PSA rising besides cancer recurrence, so don't panic! For more info see this post in another recent thread: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...l=1#post263672

Posts.Title: Shorter penis after prostate removal?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I've read this term (1/1000) before. What does 1/1000 mean. Does it mean with each core that is taken there is only a chance of hitting the cancer 1 in 1000. No, it doesn't work that way. The chance of hitting the cancer depends mostly on the percentage of prostate that contains cancer. For example, if the tumor is 10% of the prostate, then a single core has around 10% chance (actually a little more because the core has length vs being a single point) of hitting tumor or about a 90% chance of missing. But a 2nd core has another more-or-less independent 10% chance of hitting the cancer. For cancer involving 10% of the prostate the chances of all 12 cores missing tumor (false negative) would be 0.9 ^12 = 28% or about a 72% chance of finding it.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Race The biopsy is a sampling process, and I've never seen a good explanation of the probabilities. As outlined in my post above, a conservative upper bound for the probability of a false negative is (1-p)^n where p is the fraction of the prostate involved and n is the number of cores.

Posts.Content: Yes. The following papers talk about the concept of insignificant biochemical recurrence (iBCR) potentially due to bits of benign prostate tissue: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23706588 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19406457 I have the first one (Donin et. al.) and can email to you if you like but here is an excerpt: "A PSA >0.2 ng/mL may develop because of local, lymphatic, or systemic recurrent prostate cancer or may be because of the presence of residual benign prostate tissue. Differentiating between these etiologies in the early stages of recurrence is not possible using presently available diagnostic technology. We have previously reported that microscopic benign prostate tissue is often identified at the apical and bladder neck soft tissue margins during RP and speculated that these benign glands may contribute to measureable PSA associated with prolonged PSA doubling time (PSADT). We have previously reported that a postprostatectomy PSA >0.2 ng/mL in association with a PSADT >36 months is attributable to residual benign microscopic prostatic elements. Men fulfilling these criteria in the present study were classified as exhibiting iBCR likely because of benign prostatic tissue and therefore none of these men were offered salvage radiation therapy (SRT)."

Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shenanigans Seen my surgeon Friday. I really like him. Had a 830 appointment and was there till almost 11. I had a lot of questions an he was very patient with me. I didn't realize how long I had been there and told him how sorry I was his reply was " Don't worry about the time, this is about you." He gave me his cell number and said if I had any other questions to call him. LOL I had planned to have my surgery in three weeks. His schedule was full. Looked at me and said, " How about this coming Wednesday. Took a couple of deep breaths and said yes. This Monday I will see the anesthesiologist to be cleared for surgery and If cleared then Wed. morning will have my surgery. Lots to do in a very short time. Belated welcome to the forum, Shenanigans. It sounds like you've found a very good surgeon at least in terms of compassion and accessibility. Mine was the same way and it is great. However, looking at your prior posts it appears you were just diagnosed on Oct 15 so I presume the biopsy was done only 2-3 weeks ago? If so, you really should be waiting another few week (maybe that's what you meant by originally wanting to have it done in about 3 weeks). You really want to wait at least 6 weeks, ideally 8 to let the inflammation from the biopsy subside. The inflammation you still have at this time can seriously compromise the nerve sparing (increasing risk of ED or positive margins) and/or resecting the prostate cleanly off the rectum without tearing the rectum or nicking the prostate capsule (which is thin as tissue paper) and leaving cancer behind. I believe you said you picked up Walsh's book, he does a good job explaining this (see pg 26. In general, but especially for you as a low risk GS6 there is no need to rush. If your surgeon is busy in 3-4 weeks, then put it off for 6 or 8 or 10 or 12 if necessary. As compassionate and accommodating as your surgeon appears to be, I'm sure he won't mind if you reconsider the timing (and if he does mind, that would be a red flag). BTW, did you ask him for his personal outcome statistics particularly positive margin rates for pT2 and pT3 cases?

Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: Today I am 10 weeks post-op and I wanted to give a breif update (for details of my surgery see my initial post here: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...015#post191015) In terms of continence, while there is still day-to-day variability, I am now down to a single pad most days (sometimes barely needed) and none at night. I leaked badly the first week and then had significant progress the next two weeks and then plateaued at 3-4 pads per day for the next several weeks. At the suggestion of my local uro I began biofeedback PT at six weeks and although I have not done many of the suggested exercises besides Kegals and stretching I had a burst of improvement the last couple weeks. I’m not sure how much of this is attributable to the biofeedback, Kegals, walking, normal healing, or whatever, but in any event I’m very pleased with how its progressed. On the potency front, I starting to see some partial but encouraging response at 6 weeks when I started 10mg Cialis q3d. I found things worked much better when standing or using a constriction ring. The response improved rapidly over the last couple weeks and this past weekend with 20mg Cialis and using a constriction band I had an excellent result and some great sex! So the nerves are suddenly really coming around. I'm sure my relative youth and good health have a lot to do with it, but I still think this rapid recovery is somewhat remarkable especially given that the nerve sparing on the right side was only partial due to the palpable tumor on that side. I have to think that the 300mg Irbesartan I am taking daily since my operation has played a significant role in this. For those who recently had or soon will be having RP, this is something to consider with seemingly very little downside:http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23030689 As upright posture / constriction ring have a marked effect, it seems that some venous leakage is part of the picture for me. From what I have read it sounds like venous leakage is a irreversible condition but one that would be unusual to manifest as a side effect of RP so soon post-op -- especially in patient having successful nerve sparing and doing rehab. So I am hoping it may be a relatively slight condition that actually existed pre-operatively and that will not be sufficient to cause problems once the nerves and blood supply fully recover. My surgeon says this venous leakage is does not portend negatively for me and he expects a return to my preoperative performance over the long term.
